Graphical abstract A methanol catalyst based on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) was prepared and mixed with four different solid acids, a pure γ-Al2O3, a SiO2-doped γ-Al2O3, an AlPO4-doped γ-Al2O3 and the zeolite H-MFI 400, respectively. These admixed catalyst systems were tested in the direct synthesis of dimethyl ether from CO-rich synthesis gas (CO:H2 =1), which is typical for biomass-derived synthesis gas. Reactions were carried out in a laboratory plant at 250°C and 51bar for 120h time-on-stream followed by catalyst passivation with O2 and regeneration by hydrogenation. After catalyst regeneration, the reaction was run again for another 72h. The catalyst system containing the zeolite exhibited highest CO-conversion. However, all catalysts showed a drop of activity after the passivation- and regeneration-process and the system with the SiO2-doped γ-Al2O3 showed the lowest loss of activity. Investigation of the catalysts after reaction by N2O-pulse chemisorption and XRD revealed that agglomeration of catalyst species took place leading to an increased Cu0-particle size for all systems. This phenomenon was less pronounced in the case of the system containing the SiO2-doped γ-Al2O3. Thus, the main cause of catalyst deactivation was found to be sintering of the catalytically active components. Keywords Dimethyl ether Single step synthesis Solid acid Biomass Synthesis gas 1 Introduction Dimethyl ether (DME) has gained enormous interest over the last years and is considered to be one of the most promising alternative fuels [1]. Applications of DME shifted from its use as propellant and chemical feedstock to various applications as an energy carrier [2]. The main use of DME today is as a LPG-substitute [3] and it can also be used as a diesel-substitute. In fact, Volvo announced the commercialization of their DME-trucks in North America in 2015 and DME will be produced by Oberon fuels [4]. The new possible applications of DME lead to an immense increase of the global production capacities from 0.03 MTPY in 2003 to 5 MTPY in 2009 and a further increase is ongoing [5]. The industrial production of DME proceeds via the dehydration of methanol using a solid acid, e.g. γ-Al2O3 or a zeolite, as catalyst. However, DME can also be produced directly from synthesis gas in a single step synthesis. In the latter case, a dual catalyst system is required and typically an admixed catalyst system containing a methanol catalyst (Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, CZA) and a solid acid is applied. Eqs. (1)–(3) express the main reaction pathways, i.e. methanol synthesis (1), methanol dehydration (2) and the water-gas shift reaction (3). The overall reaction is described by Eq. (4) [6]. (1) 2CO+4H2 →2CH3OH (2) 2CH3OH→CH3OCH3 +H2O (3) CO+H2O→H2 +CO2 Overall: (4) CO+3H2 →CH3OCH3 +CO2 The single step synthesis of DME has been tested only on pilot scale so far [7–9] and catalyst-deactivation, -passivation and -recovery phenomena have not been investigated sufficiently. One of the first studies in this field has been carried out by Peng et al. [10]. The deactivation of the admixed catalyst system in the single step synthesis was compared to the deactivation of each catalyst component in its respective reaction, i.e. methanol synthesis and methanol dehydration. The results showed that each catalyst component is rather stable in its respective process. However, if the catalysts are combined in an admixed system a strong deactivation was observed. It was concluded that the loss of activity is a result of close interactions between the catalyst components, which might lead to a migration of active Cu-species. Studies of Luan et al. focused on catalyst regeneration [11], employing O2, N2O and CO2 for the treatment of the spent catalyst system. Initial performance of the catalyst system in terms of CO-conversion and specific Cu-surface area could be re-established if O2 was used in the regeneration procedure. The decrease of the Cu-surface area during the reaction indicated, that sintering of active Cu-species is the main cause of deactivation and that the solid acid has no significant influence on catalyst deactivation. Barbosa et al. studied the influence of the synthesis gas composition (H2/CO=1 and 2) on catalyst stability [12]. After 300min time-on-stream a strong deactivation was observed for a H2/CO ratio of 1, whereas catalyst activity stayed constant for a H2/CO ratio of 2. Investigation of the catalyst after reaction by FTIR and TGA revealed in both cases the presence of hydrocarbons on the surface of the solid acid H-ZSM-5. However, product selectivity was constant in the reaction with H2/CO=1, despite the strong deactivation. This suggests that the dehydration step in the DME synthesis process is not affected by the formation of hydrocarbons and coke. Therefore, they conclude that catalyst deactivation is mainly due to the formation of hydrocarbons on the dehydration component, which are subsequently transferred to the CZA-catalyst and the generation of hydrocarbons and coke is favored in case of H2/CO=1. A comparison between a fixed-bed reactor and a bubble column reactor focusing on catalyst stability was carried out by Wang et al. [13]. After 180h, catalyst deactivation was much stronger in the bubble column reactor. Therefore, a possible deactivation of the catalyst caused by reaction heat could be excluded, since heat removal is more efficient in bubble column reactors. Further experiments showed that water, which could not escape from the catalyst pores due to the high oil temperature in the bubble column reactor, lead to sintering of active Cu-species. According to Zhang et al., the main cause for deactivation of the catalyst system is sintering of the CZA-component and coking is only a secondary phenomenon [14]. However, it is assumed that other effects, caused by the interaction between the CZA-component and the solid acid play an important role regarding long-term stability. The influence of different solid acids (i.e. γ-Al2O3, NH4-ZSM-5, H-ZSM-5) on catalyst stability was tested by Abu-Dahrieh et al. [15]. and the admixed catalyst system with H-ZSM-5 exhibited highest stability. TPO measurements showed that coke accumulated on the CZA-component, on the solid acid and also between both components. Thus, coking was identified as the main reason for catalyst deactivation in this study. Various studies on catalyst-deactivation and -regeneration were carried out by Aguayo et al. In one of these studies the use of H2/CO as feed for DME synthesis was compared to the use of H2/CO2 [16]. Employing H2/CO2, a higher long-term stability of the catalyst was observed than in the case of H2/CO. The presence of CO2 supports the reverse water-gas shift reaction, which produces water. Adsorption of thus produced water prevents pore blockage by coke and leads to higher stability. Moreover, if NaH-ZSM-5 was used as solid acid the initial activity could be re-established after regeneration, whereas the system with γ-Al2O3 could not be regenerated as well, due to its low thermal stability. The coking behavior of admixed catalysts was further investigated [17] and TPO-as well as NH3-TPD-measurements proved that coking took place. However, the acidity was not influenced by the formation of byproducts. Moreover, the catalyst could be regenerated completely, so that deactivation by sintering could be excluded. Thus, it was concluded that the presence of coke on the CZA-component lead to catalyst deactivation. The influence of various reaction parameters on catalyst stability was also investigated [17,18]. It was reported that temperatures above 250°C lead to a reduction of coking and the addition of water decreased the formation of coke. As long as the temperature stayed below 300°C sintering of the Cu-species did not occur. Furthermore, high pressure supported coke formation and a pressure of 20bar lead to the most stable CO-conversion. Within this work, admixed catalyst systems containing different solid acids were tested focusing on their long-term stability in the single step synthesis of DME. CO-rich synthesis gas was employed with a H2/CO-ratio of 1, which is typical for biomass-derived synthesis gas. The work concentrates not only on the long-term stability of the catalysts and their deactivation, but also on their passivation after reaction and regeneration by reductive treatment with H2. Such investigations are mandatory regarding practical aspects such as safe removal of the catalyst system from the reactor, recovery and reuse of costly catalysts as well as catalyst storage. Furthermore, the influence of the solid acid on activity and stability and its interaction with the CZA-component are main topics, which are addressed within this work. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts The admixed catalyst system for the single step synthesis of DME comprised a methanol catalyst (CZA) and a solid acid. The CZA catalyst was synthesized by co-precipitation. A solution of 14.03g Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O, 10.75g Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O and 3.50g Al(NO3)3∙9H2O in 150mL deionized H2O was slowly dropped into 100mL of deionized H2O at 70°C. A Na2CO3-solution (1M) was used as precipitating agent and the pH was adjusted to 7–8 during the whole process. Afterwards, the obtained light-blue suspension was aged for 1h. The precipitate was thoroughly washed, separated by centrifugation and finally filtrated. The filter cake was dried for 12h at 80°C and finally calcined (1h at 175°C and 4h at 350°C). The obtained CZA-catalyst was ground and mean sizes of the particles were between 80 and 355μm. Four different solid acids were used as dehydration components in the admixed catalyst systems: γ-Al2O3 (AA, from Alfa Aesar GmbH & Co., KG), SIRALOX 30 (SiAl, a SiO2-doped γ-Al2O3 from SASOL, Germany GmbH), HS Alumina (AlPO, a AlPO4-doped γ-Al2O3 from SASOL Germany GmbH) and zeolite H-MFI 400 (MFI400, from Süd-Chemie, AG). All solid acids were ground and mean particle sizes were between 80 and 355μm. The admixed catalyst systems were prepared by mechanically mixing of the CZA-catalyst with the solid acid in a weight ratio of 1:1. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Metal loadings were determined by SEM-EDX and XRF. The EDX analysis was carried out employing an INCAPentaFET-x3 unit from Oxford Instruments on several locations of the catalysts and SEM images were recorded with a FESEM DSM 982 Gemini microscope (ZEISS) equipped with a backscatter detector. A vario EL CUBE instrument from Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH was used for elemental analysis (CHNS-mode). XRF analyses were carried out employing a SIEMENS SRS 303 sequence-spectrometer and the obtained data were evaluated with the Siemens SemiQuant 3000 software 2.0. Rh was used as radiation-source with an accelerating voltage of 20–60kV (at 5mA) and a flow meter as well as a scintillation counter were used as detectors. Specific surface area (BET method, p/p 0 =0.05-0.20), total pore volume (p/p 0 =0.99) and micropore surface (V-t-method, p/p 0 =0.10−0.30) were determined by N2-physisorption using a Quantachrome Nova 2000e instrument. XRD diffractograms were recorded using a PANalytical X'PERT-PRO diffractometer. Cu-Kα-X-radiation (0.154nm) was employed and diffractograms were taken in a 1h measurement over a 2θ range from 5 to 120°. The average crystallite size of the reduced Cu species was determined by the Scherrer equation [19] with a correction for the instrumental broadening. H2-TPR, NH3-TPD and N2O-pulse chemisorption were carried out using an AutoChem 2950HP device from Micromeritics. H2-TPR was used to investigate reducibility of the catalysts. The samples were dried at 200°C while under Ar, cooled down and then exposed to a diluted H2 atmosphere and heated up to 300°C with a heating rate of 2°C/min. The H2 uptake was recorded employing a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). NH3-TPD was employed to determine the acidity of the respective systems. The samples were dried at 300°C while under He and after cooling down saturated with NH3 for 90min. Afterwards, the samples were heated up to 800°C in a He-flow. The release of NH3 was recorded by a TCD-detector. For determination of the specific Cu surface area N2O-pulse chemisorption was applied. The samples were reduced by H2-TPR as described above. At 60°C pulses of N2O were introduced into the sample cell. Redundant N2O was collected in a cold trap and the evolved N2 was detected and recorded by the TCD-detector. The Cu surface area was calculated by assuming a surface density of 1.46×1019 Cu atoms/m2 [20]. For the determination of Brønsted- and Lewis-acid sites pyridine-adsorption experiments with FTIR were carried out at Leibniz Institute for Catalysis. Thin self-supporting wafers were prepared and transferred to an in situ sample cell with CaF2-windows, which was then placed in a Bruker IFS 66 spectrometer. The sample was dried in an air-flow at 400°C for 1h followed by saturation with pyridine at 100°C for 1h. Physisorbed pyridine was then removed in vacuum. FTIR-spectra were recorded at different temperatures with a resolution of 2cm−1 and 100 scans. The relative concentrations of Brønsted- and Lewis-acid sites were determined from the area of the absorption bands at 1545cm−1 (Brønsted-acid sites) and 1450cm−1 (Lewis-acid sites). 2.3 Catalyst testing The catalyst screening was carried out in a continuously operating laboratory plant (Fig. 1 ) Core of the laboratory plant was a fixed-bed reactor with a volume of 60.3mL, which was designed for pressures up to 100bar and temperatures up to 450°C. Gases were dosed by Mass Flow Controllers (MFC) and all gas flows were analyzed by an online-GC (HP 6890, Agilent) with two columns (RT®-U-BOND and RT-Msieve 5A, RESTEK) and two detectors (TCD and FID). For all reactions 2g of the admixed catalyst system were placed in the reactor. Reduction of CuO to active Cu° species was carried out in a reducing atmosphere (2% H2 in Ar) while heating up to 240°C with 17°C/h. Afterwards, the gas flow was switched to pure H2 and the temperature was increased to 250°C within 1h. After keeping the system for 2h under these conditions it was rinsed with Ar and subjected to pressure (p =51bar). A gas mixture with a (H2 +CO):(Ar+N2) ratio of 3:7 was employed and a WHSV of 4.19h−1 was adjusted. The H2:CO-ratio was 1:1 and the Ar:N2-ratio was 6:1. The following equations were applied to calculate conversions and selectivities: X CO = ( c CO,0 − c CO ) c CO , 0 × 100 with X CO: CO-conversion (%) c CO,0: CO-concentration at reactor inlet (%) c CO: CO-concentration at reactor outlet (%) S i = ξ i × c i ( c CO,0 − c CO ) × 100 with S i: selectivity of component i (%) ci : concentration of component i (%) ξi : amount of C-atoms in component i After 120h time-on-stream, the pressure was reduced to atmospheric pressure and temperature was reduced to 200°C. Additionally, the laboratory plant was thoroughly purged with Ar. Finally, the passivation process was started using the conditions summarized in Table 1 . During this process the evolution of CO2 was monitored by online-GC to ensure complete coke-removal. After completed regeneration the reactor was cooled down to 180°C and purged with Ar again. Thereupon, the catalyst system was activated a second time with 2vol% H2 in Ar while heating the system up to 240°C with 5°C/h. After keeping the conditions constant for 2h the reactor was subjected to a 100% H2-atmosphere and heated to 250°C with 10°C/h. After keeping the system at this temperature for 2h, DME synthesis was started again under the conditions described above. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The composition of catalyst CZA was determined by XRF- and EDX-measurements and the ratio CuO:ZnO:Al2O3 was 56:36:7wt%. The Cu°-surface area was determined by N2O-pulse-chemisorption. CZA shows a high Cu°-surface area of 83m2/gmetal, which comes along with high metal dispersion of 12.9% and small Cu°-particles with a mean size of 6.8nm. Results of N2-physisorption experiments are summarized in Table 2 . CZA exhibits a comparatively high BET-surface of 96m2/g. The addition of SiO2 and AlPO4 to γ-Al2O3 results in higher surface areas as can be seen for the solid acids SiAl and AlPO. The largest surface area is displayed by the zeolite MFI400, which also possesses, as expected, the largest number of micropores. The reducibility of CZA was investigated by H2-TPR and the reduction curve is shown in Fig. 2 . The maximum of the main peak is at 194°C and a less intense peak is located at 171°C. The latter peak is due to the presence of different CuO species [21–23] or stepwise reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) and then to Cu° [24]. For the solid acids, NH3-TPD was carried out and the respective curves are shown in Fig. 3 . Table 3 summarizes the NH3-uptake and the total uptake is compared to the uptake in the range between 150 and 500°C. Peaks that appear in this range represent weak acid sites, which are known to be crucial for methanol dehydration to DME [25,26]. The results indicate that addition of SiO2 or AlPO4 to γ-Al2O3 does not only lead to a higher catalyst surface area (see Table 2) but also to an increase in acidity. Thus, SiAl and AlPO are more acidic than AA. However, concerning the quantity of weak acid sites, SiAl exhibits the highest NH3-uptake in the range between 150 and 500°C and hence possesses the highest quantity of weak acid sites followed by AA and AlPO. Compared to the other dehydration catalysts, zeolite MFI400 contains the lowest quantity of acid sites regarding the total amount as well as the amount of weak acid sites. To estimate the amount of Brønsted- and Lewis-acid sites, pyridine-adsorption of the dehydration catalysts was investigated by FTIR-spectroscopy at 150°C (Fig. 4 ). All catalysts show the typical bands of adsorbed pyridine at around 1617 and 1450cm−1, which indicate Lewis-acid sites. The bands of MFI400 and SiAl are at somewhat higher wavelengths (1620 and 1619cm−1) than those of AA and AlPO (1614 and 1616cm−1) indicating strong Lewis-acid sites in the case of MFI400 and SiAl [27] and moderate Lewis-acid sites in the case of AA and AlPO [28]. The catalysts SiAl and MFI400 show additional bands at 1544 and 1543cm−1 respectively, that can be assigned to Brønsted-acid sites. Band intensities were analyzed to determine the ratio of Lewis- to Brønsted-acid sites (Table 4 ). According to the results of pyridine adsorption experiments, acidity of all catalysts is dominated by Lewis-acid sites and SiAl exhibits a higher percentage of Brønsted-acid sites than zeolite MFI400. The amount of Lewis-acid sites decreases in the order AlPO>SiAl>AA>MFI400 and the same tendency was observed by NH3-TPD. Fig. 5 shows the diffraction pattern of the CZA-catalyst and Fig. 6 the diffraction patterns of the dehydration catalysts. The reflections of CZA are relatively broad indicating small crystallites. The broad reflection at 2θ =30−40° is formed by overlapping signals of CuO, ZnO and Al2O3. MFI400 shows the typical reflections of a zeolite, especially in the 2θ range between 20 and 30°. All alumina-based catalysts show the typical reflections of γ-Al2O3. The diffractogram of SiAl shows also a broad reflection at 2θ ≈22°, which can be attributed to amorphous SiO2. Catalyst AlPO does not show any reflections that can be assigned to AlPO4. 3.2 Catalyst testing The admixed catalyst systems comprised the methanol catalyst CZA and a solid acid for methanol dehydration, i.e. AA, SiAl, AlPO and MFI400, respectively. Each system was tested in a fixed-bed reactor at 250°C and 51bar for 120h. Afterwards, the catalyst system was passivated by subjecting it to an O2-containing atmosphere thereby possibly removing impurities from the catalyst surface. The maximum temperature of the regeneration process was 270°C (see Table 1). Higher temperatures were avoided to prevent sintering of the active Cu-species. After reduction of the catalyst system, the reaction was started again and run for another 72h. Fig. 7 shows the CO-conversion over the complete time span for the four catalyst systems. The mixture of CZA and MFI400 reached highest CO-conversion followed by the catalyst system CZA/AA. Modification of γ-Al2O3 by incorporation of SiO2 and AlPO4, respectively, lowered the catalytic activity of the corresponding catalyst systems CZA/SiAl and CZA/AlPO. After the regeneration procedure a distinctive drop of CO-conversion was observed for all systems except for the system containing SiAl as dehydration component. In this case only a slight decrease of CO conversion was observed. All catalyst systems were investigated after 192h time-on-stream and EDX measurements revealed low amounts of carbon (<2%) on the catalyst surfaces. Elemental analysis was also employed to determine carbon contents and to confirm the results from EDX measurements. Thus, the following amounts of carbon were determined: 0.7% (CZA/AA), 0.7% (CZA/SiAl), 1.3% (CZA/AlPO) and 1.0% (CZA/MFI400). Regarding DME- and CO2-selectivity, the typical values according to Eq. (4) were observed, i.e. DME was produced with nearly 67% and CO2 with nearly 33% selectivity (Fig. 8 a). After regeneration, selectivity changed slightly but returned to the values observed before passivation within a few hours. Compared to DME/CO2-selectivity, methanol and hydrocarbon selectivity was very low (<1.5%, Fig. 8b and c). While DME-selectivity decreased immediately after regeneration, selectivity for the byproducts CO2, methanol and hydrocarbons increased nearly always. However, this phenomenon was unincisive and in most cases almost the same selectivities as before passivation were observed after a few hours. The results show that passivation and regeneration of the catalyst systems lead to a decrease of catalytic activity (Fig. 7). Since only small amounts of carbon were deposited on the surface, coking can be excluded as the main reason for catalyst deactivation. Moreover, in the case of deactivation by coking, passivation/regeneration should result in an increase of catalytic activity and not in a drop of CO-conversion. To exclude the possibility that the temperature of the passivation- and regeneration-procedure has been too high, the reaction was repeated employing the catalyst system CZA/MFI400. This time, the maximum temperature of passivation/regeneration was 250°C instead of 270°C (see Table 1), i.e. the maximum temperature was equal to reaction temperature. CO-conversion is shown in Fig. 9 and despite the lower temperature, a drop of CO-conversion was still observed. Hence, the temperature is not decisive for the loss of catalytic activity and further parameters have to be considered. To elucidate the changes of catalyst performance, investigations on the catalyst morphology after the complete procedure (reaction, passivation, reactivation and second reaction) were carried out. A well-known reason for decreasing catalytic activity is the agglomeration of active particles leading to a loss of catalytically active surface area. To estimate the extent of Cu°-species after the second reaction period, catalyst mixtures were separated and CZA components were investigated by N2O-pulse-chemisorption. Compared to the unused CZA catalyst (Cu°-surface area of 83m2/gmetal, see above), lower Cu°-surface areas of 54 (CZA/AA), 50 (CZA/AlPO) and 57m2/gmetal (CZA/MFI400) were observed after reaction. Mean particle sizes increased from 6.8nm before reaction (see above) to 10.3 (CZA/AA), 11.2 (CZA/AlPO) and 9.9nm (CZA/MFI400) after reaction. These data could not be determined for catalyst CZA/SiAl, since the catalyst components could not be separated accurately after reaction. Thus, XRD measurements were also carried out for all catalyst systems (Fig. 10 ) and crystallite sizes were calculated using the Scherrer-equation. The catalyst system with AA as dehydration catalyst exhibited Cu°-crystallites with diameters of 20nm while the corresponding systems with AlPO and MFI400 exhibited crystallite diameters of 17 and 15nm, respectively. The catalyst system containing SiAl as dehydration catalyst showed Cu°-crystallite sizes around 9nm after reaction. Thus, catalyst CZA/SiAl was less influenced by the passivation- and regeneration-process and active Cu-species did not agglomerate to significantly larger particles as in the case of the other catalyst systems. This is also in accordance with the results from catalyst testing (Fig. 7). The admixed catalyst with SiAl as solid acid exhibited the lowest decrease of CO-conversion after its regeneration. Hence, the modification of γ-Al2O3 with SiO2 increased the stability of the catalyst system. There are various studies on the effect of doping γ-Al2O3 with SiO2 or AlPO4. In general, there is a broad agreement that such a modification leads to an increase in dehydration activity and a decrease in coking. However, these studies comprise only the dehydration of methanol to DME and not the single step synthesis of DME [28–32]. A study on the single step synthesis was carried out by Peng et al. [33]. AlPO4-based catalysts were employed and higher CO-conversions were observed compared to unmodified γ-Al2O3. In all these studies, the superiority of SiO2- and AlPO4-doped γ-Al2O3 was attributed to the lower acidity compared to pure γ-Al2O3, resulting in a decreased generation of hydrocarbons and thus in higher DME selectivity. However, this does not apply to SiAl and AlPO, which was shown by the results of NH3-TPD and pyridine-adsorption (Tables 3 and 4). In fact, a correlation between catalyst acidity and its influence on catalyst stability and activity cannot be drawn from the results obtained within this work. All catalyst systems show almost complete dehydration, i.e. DME and CO2 are the dominating products and the percentage of side products (methanol and hydrocarbons) does not exceed 2%. Moreover, the differentiation between Lewis- and Brønsted-acid sites (Table 4) cannot explain the observed performances. All systems exhibit Lewis-acid sites while SiAl and MFI400 additionally exhibit Brønsted-acid sites, which are not directly reflected in their catalytic behavior. The obtained results indicate that the loss of catalytic activity is rather due to sintering of active sites than catalyst coking. This finding is in accordance with a study of Zhang et al. [14]. whereas in most studies coking is assumed to cause deactivation [11,12,15–18]. However, a comparison between these studies should be carefully drawn since different reaction conditions were chosen. Naturally, these have an immense influence on the catalysts as can be clearly seen from the work of Zhang et al. [14]. and Ereña et al. [17]. In a recent study on CZA/ZSM-5 catalysts, Ordomsky et al. showed that catalyst deactivation is a result of copper sintering, copper oxidation, migration of copper species and ion exchange with hydroxyl groups of the zeolite thus revealing the complexity of such processes [34]. Regarding the results of this work, two aspects stand out: The comparatively high CO conversion of the catalyst system CZA/MFI400 and the improved catalyst stability of the system with SiAl. The superiority of zeolites over alumina has been known before [26,35–37]. but a stringent explanation for this difference in activity is still lacking. Regarding stability, the experiments reveal that SiAl increases the stability of the admixed catalyst system and agglomeration of active Cu-species is reduced. A deeper understanding of these phenomena can support rational optimization of such catalysts. As stated above, differences in acidity is not the main reason for different CO-conversions. Methanol synthesis is the rate-determining step in the single step process and CO-conversion mainly depends on this reaction. Therefore, the results indicate that the solid acid does not only catalyze the dehydration step but also influences the methanol synthesis step. This influence of the solid acid is not only observable in the case of admixed catalyst systems but also in the case of bifunctional catalysts, i.e. catalyst systems that combine active sites for methanol generation and dehydration in one compound [38]. 4 Conclusion The dehydration component in admixed catalysts for the single step synthesis of DME has a strong influence on activity and stability of the catalyst systems. Mixing a CZA methanol catalyst with zeolite MFI400 resulted in higher CO-conversions than mixing CZA with γ-Al2O3-based catalysts. However, this system was affected during catalyst-passivation and -regeneration thus leading to a drop of CO-conversion between the first and the second use. The addition of SiO2 and AlPO4 to γ-Al2O3 lead to a decrease of catalytic activity compared to pure γ-Al2O3. However, a mixture of CZA and SiO2-doped γ-Al2O3 (SiAl) resulted in an increased stability of the admixed system. No significant drop of CO-conversion after passivation/regeneration was observed. The investigation of all spent catalyst systems by N2O-pulse chemisorption and XRD revealed clearly increased particle sizes of the active Cu°-species after passivation/reactivation except for the system containing SiAl. Hence, SiAl prevents the agglomeration of catalytically active sites. The results also indicate that sintering is the main cause for catalyst-deactivation and there is no evidence for significant deactivation by coking. Ongoing studies concentrate on understanding the influence of the dehydration component on catalyst activity and stability. A deeper understanding can lead to an optimized synthesis of bifunctional catalyst systems for the single step synthesis of DME with higher CO-conversion and better long-term stability. Moreover, reaction conditions of the passivation- and regeneration-procedures will be studied more in detail, so that oxidation of the catalyst systems can be carried out in a safe way and without sacrificing their activity. coredata.dc:description: A methanol catalyst based on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) was prepared and mixed with four different solid acids, a pure γ-Al2O3, a SiO2-doped γ-Al2O3, an AlPO4-doped γ-Al2O3 and the zeolite H-MFI 400, respectively. These admixed catalyst systems were tested in the direct synthesis of dimethyl ether from CO-rich synthesis gas (CO:H2 =1), which is typical for biomass-derived synthesis gas. Reactions were carried out in a laboratory plant at 250°C and 51bar for 120h time-on-stream followed by catalyst passivation with O2 and regeneration by hydrogenation. After catalyst regeneration, the reaction was run again for another 72h. The catalyst system containing the zeolite exhibited highest CO-conversion. However, all catalysts showed a drop of activity after the passivation- and regeneration-process and the system with the SiO2-doped γ-Al2O3 showed the lowest loss of activity. Investigation of the catalysts after reaction by N2O-pulse chemisorption and XRD revealed that agglomeration of catalyst species took place leading to an increased Cu0-particle size for all systems. This phenomenon was less pronounced in the case of the system containing the SiO2-doped γ-Al2O3. Thus, the main cause of catalyst deactivation was found to be sintering of the catalytically active components.
coredata.dc:title: Passivation and reactivation of catalyst systems for the single step synthesis of dimethyl ether from CO-rich synthesis gas
